abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome is satisfactory,
            sustainability likely, but only modest institutional
            development impacts were achieved. Lessons underline the
            unique, and significant nature of this project,
            demonstrating that, by and large, a community-based
            nutrition project can produce impressive results. It has
            shown that an emergency situation effectively dealt with,
            can become the starting point of a larger-scale national
            operation, whose key success was the involvement of an
            experienced private sector management institution, of a
            strong political commitment, and of an empowered community
            participation. However, on project design, and preparation,
            it would have been better had the roles, and
            responsibilities of the coordinating been clearly defined,
            to avoid unnecessary delays, or lack of human, and financial
            resources. The ambitious performance criteria led to too
            much focus on treating symptoms, than on prevention, whereas
            a flexible approach could have adapted appropriately to
            implementation needs. These implementation needs showed that
            more information on cost-effectiveness, and the longer-term
            impact of the approach was needed to evaluate results,
            including the evaluation of contracting to different
            providers. From the institutional point of view, it is
            important to allow for competition among executing agencies
            to promote capacity building, and stimulate
            cost-effectiveness, by testing different approaches for
            adequate delivery services.

18153886.theme: Rural services and infrastructure,Urban services and housing for the poor,Nutrition and food security,Vulnerability assessment and monitoring,Administrative and civil service reform
18153886.majtheme: Rural development,Urban development,Human development,Social protection and risk management,Public sector governance

abstracts.cdata!:
The Community Nutrition Project
            development objectives are to 1) halt a further
            deterioration in the nutritional status of the most
            vulnerable groups (malnourished children under 3 years of
            age and pregnant and nursing mothers) in targeted poor urban
            neighborhoods; 2) provide potable water to unserviced
            neighborhoods of the nutrition program; and 3) enhance
            household food security in poor rural and urban areas during
            critical periods of vulnerability. Its implementation
            objectives are to demonstrate the feasibility of targeted,
            efficient and cost-effective delivery of community nutrition
            interventions and execute a poverty-oriented program through
            a privately operated agency. The project consists of three
            major components. The first encompasses a nutrition program
            consisting of information, education and communication (IEC)
            interlocutors supported by supplementary feeding for the
            target population in urban areas and a small fund for
            research and development. The second component funds a water
            program in the targeted neighborhoods of the nutrition
            program. The third component is a pilot rural household food
            security program. As an integral part of these components,
            there will be a package of managerial health and technical
            assistance and training to build local capacity for
            nutrition/health services delivery, and a management
            information system for monitoring and evaluation.
